headline: General Motors has ’underappreciated upside potential’: Benchmark
summary: Investing.com -- Benchmark initiated coverage on General Motors (NYSE:GM) with a Buy rating and a $65 price target, citing what it calls “underappreciated upside potential” in a durable and cash-generative U.S. industrial franchise.

headline: Top auto stock picks: How to play the evolving EV sector
summary: RBC Capital Markets global autos analyst Tom Narayan sits down with Market Domination host Josh Lipton to outline his thinking about the electric vehicle (EV) space ahead of Tesla (TSLA) earnings this week. Narayan talks about his Tesla earnings expectations, the recent Uber (UBER) and Lucid (LCID) deal, recent policy changes, and some of his top stock picks in the auto industry. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Domination here.

headline: Alphabet and Tesla Earnings, Powell Speech and More: What to Watch This Week
summary: Earnings season rolls on this week with the first of the Magnificent Seven tech names to report, Tesla and Alphabet. New economic data will shed more light on how tariffs are affecting consumer and business spending, and Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell is slated to speak on bank regulation.

headline: US stocks advance, Treasury yields soften with earnings, trade deals in focus
summary: NEW YORK (Reuters) -Wall Street stocks advanced on Monday and Treasury yields softened at the top of a busy week of corporate earnings reports, as negotiations between the United States and its trading partners ramped up in the face of a fast-approaching August 1 deadline.  All three major U.S. stock indexes moved higher in opposition to their European counterparts, and the dollar weakened against the yen in the wake of Japan's weekend elections.  "You're seeing an apparent return of U.S. dominance for equity investors, and it is being driven by a very resilient U.S. consumer," said Oliver Pursche, senior vice president at Wealthspire Advisors in New York, who added, "There’s an increasing realization that the back-and-forth on tariffs is not anywhere near over, and that's pressuring European shares, and Asian shares to a certain extent."

"You're seeing an apparent return of U.S. dominance for equity investors, and it is being driven by a very resilient U.S. consumer," said Oliver Pursche, senior vice president at Wealthspire Advisors in New York, who added, "There’s an increasing realization that the back-and-forth on tariffs is not anywhere near over, and that's pressuring European shares, and Asian shares to a certain extent."
